When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it is derived (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily go back), it often finds itself in a different environment from that in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it had before.
The original population has not changed at all, it always needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to resemble less and less the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they will no longer be considered members of the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which human destiny is dictated by a underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: technological development itself occurs beyond the influence of cultural and political factors, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
The massive possession of cars also leads to an increased incidence of road accidents, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat bodily injuries.

If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have been able to conquer Britain just as she did for the rest of Europe.
It seems that goats were domesticated for the first time about 10,000 years ago in the Zagros Mountains in Iran.
The ancient cultures and tribes started keeping them close to them to have easy access to milk, fur, meat, and skins.

Domestic goats were usually kept in herds that wandered on the hills or other grazing areas, often cared for by shepherds who were most often children or adolescents, similar to the more well-known term of shepherds. These pastoral methods have always been in use today.
“Wagonways” were built in England as early as the 16th century.

Although the tracks for wagons were simply wooden planks laid parallel to each other, they allowed horses pulling them to reach higher speeds and to carry heavier loads than on the slightly more uneven roads of the day.
The crossbars were introduced fairly early to hold the tracks in place. However, it soon became apparent that tracks would be more effective if they were fitted with a steel strip on top.
This has become a common practice, but iron caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.
The first means of locomotion was walking: Humans began walking upright two million years ago with the arrival of Homo Erectus ("upright man").
Their predecessors, the australopithecines, did not walk upright as usual.
On finds bipedal specializations in Australopithecus fossils dating back to 4.2 to 3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus could walk on two legs already seven million years ago.
We can start by living in better harmony with the environment, we can join the environmental movement, and we can even campaign to mitigate the suffering to come.
In many cases, it is symptomatic treatment. However, if we don't want a temporary solution, we must find the root of the problems and deactivate them.

It is clear that the world has changed greatly due to the scientific and technological advances made by humans, and that the problems have become more important due to the overpopulation and extravagant lifestyle of humanity.

After its adoption by the Congress on July 4, a manuscript signed by the Speaker of the House John Hancock and the Secretary of the House Charles Thomson was then sent a few blocks away to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, now known as ‘Dunlap Broadsides’.
The first public reading of the document was made by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap leaves still known to exist are the oldest known copies of the document. The original manuscript copy has not survived.
Many palaeontologists think that a group of dinosaurs survived and is still alive. They are called birds.
Very few people consider them dinosaurs because they have wings and can fly.
But there are many things about birds that still resemble a dinosaur.
They have scales on their legs and claws, they lay eggs and walk on their rear legs like T-Rexes.
Most computers used today are based on manipulating information that is coded in binary numbers.
A binary number can only have one of two values: 0 or 1. These numbers are called binary numbers, or bits for the computer jargon.
An internal poisoning may not be immediately visible. Symptoms, such as vomiting, are sufficiently general to make an immediate diagnosis impossible.
The best indicator of an internal poisoning is probably the presence of an open container of drugs or household chemical toxins.
Check the label for specific first aid instructions for this poison.
The term “insect” is used by entomologists in a formal sense to refer to this group of insects.
This term derives from an old familiarity with bed bugs, which are very well adapted to parasitize humans.
Reduces, just like bed bugs, are nidicolous, that is, adapted to live in the nest or habitat of their host.
In the United States, there are approximately 400,000 known cases of multiple sclerosis (MS), which makes it the most common neurological disease in young and middle-aged adults.
Multiple Sclerosis is a disease that affects the central nervous system, composed of the brain, spinal cord and optic nerve.
Research has shown that women are twice as likely to have MS as men.
A couple may very well feel that it is not in their interest, nor in the interest of the child, to care for a baby.
These couples can choose to make an adoption project for their baby.
In the context of adoption, the biological parents end their parental rights so that another couple can raise the child.

Many rhythms observed in physiology and behavior often depend on the presence of endogenous cycles and their production by biological clocks.
Periodic rhythms, which are not simply responses to periodic external stimuli, have been documented for most living things, including bacteria, fungi, plants and animals.
Biological clocks are self-sustaining oscillators that will continue a cycle of operation for a certain period of time, even in the absence of external stimulation.
The Hershey and Chase experiment was one of the main indications that DNA was a genetic material.
Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to implant their own DNA into a bacterium.
They conducted two experiments to label either the phage DNA with a radioactive phosphorus, or the phage protein with a radioactive sulfur.
Mutations can have many different effects depending on the type of mutation, the importance of the part of the genetic material affected and if the affected cells are germ cells.
Only germ cell mutations can be passed on to children, while other mutations can lead to the death of cells or cancer.
Ecotourism is the interest of people who wish to visit natural areas in order to enjoy the scenery, especially the fauna and flora.
Hunting, fishing, photography, bird watching, visiting parks and studying information on the ecosystem are examples of on-site activities.
One can, for example, go to see, photograph and discover the orang-utans of Borneo.
Every morning, people leave small-town countryside in their cars to go to work and cross other people who are going to work in the countryside they just left.
In this dynamic transport shuttle, each person is somehow connected to a system of private car transport and support.
Science now shows that this massively carbon-based economy has displaced the biosphere from its stable state that has supported human evolution for two million years.
Everyone is part of society and uses transport systems. Almost everyone complains about transport systems.
In developed countries, it is rare to hear so many complaints about water quality or the collapse of bridges.
Why do transportation systems generate such complaints, why do they break down daily? Are transportation engineers simply incompetent? Or is there something more fundamental going on?
Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and private vehicles between two points, and the interactions they have with each other.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because drivers' behavior cannot be predicted with a hundred percent certainty.
Unfortunately, drivers tend to act in a reasonably consistent range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonably consistent consistency and can be mathematically approximated.
To better represent traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) flow, (2) density and (3) speed.
These relationships help to plan, design, and operate highway facilities.
Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly allowed them to escape more easily from their enemies and find more efficiently food and companions.
Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along their bodies.
It gives them more places to hide from predators.
Today, the only insects that can't fold their wings are dragonflies and ephemera.
There are a few thousand years ago, an Aristarque claimed that the solar system moves around the Sun.
Some thought he was right, but many believed the opposite: that the solar system moved around the Earth, including the Sun (and even the other stars).
It seems reasonable, because the Earth doesn't seem to move, doesn't it?
The Amazon River is the second-longest and largest river on Earth. It carries more than eight times the volume of water of the second-largest river.
The Amazon is also the largest river in the world, sometimes reaching 10 km wide.
Not less than 20 percent of the water that pours out of the rivers of the planet into the oceans comes from the Amazon.
The main arm of the Amazon River is 6,387 kilometres (3,980 miles) long. It collects water from thousands of small rivers.

The ancient Egyptians of the New Kingdom were amazed by the monuments of their predecessors, who had then had more than a thousand years.
The Vatican has about 800 residents. It is the smallest independent country in the world, and the least populated.
The Vatican City writes its legislation and official communications in Italian.
Italian is also the language of everyday life used by most people who work in the state, while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies.
All citizens of the Vatican City State are Roman Catholics.

Since antiquity, peoples have been familiar with the basic chemical elements such as gold, silver and copper, because they are found in nature in their raw form and are relatively simple to mine using primitive tools.

It was more about the four states of matter (in the same order): solid, liquid, gaseous, and plasma, although he also emitted the theory that these states transform into new substances to form what we see.

Elements like calcium and potassium are considered metals. Of course, there are also metals like silver and gold.
There are also alloys that contain a small amount of non-metallic elements, such as carbon.

Like if you were to lift a heavy cart up a hill. By splitting the nucleus again and releasing a little of this energy.
Some atoms have unstable nuclei, so they tend to break apart with little or no pressure.
The moon's surface is made up of stones and dust. Its outer layer is called the crust.
The thickness of the crust is about 70 km on the visible side and 100 km on the hidden side.
It is thinner at the sea level and thicker under the continents.
There may be more maria on the near side because the crust is thinner. It was easier for lava to rise to the surface.
Theories of content are concerned with what makes people feel good or attractive.
These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires that have been internalized as they mature into adulthood.
These theories examine what drives some people to want what they do and what, in their environment, drives them to do or not do certain things.
Two popular content theories are Maslow's hierarchy of needs theory and Herzberg's two-factor theory.
In general, two behaviours can emerge when a manager becomes the boss of former colleagues. On one end of the spectrum is trying to remain the good friend (or the good friend).
This type of manager has a hard time taking unpopular decisions, leading disciplinary actions, conducting evaluations, assigning responsibilities, and holding others accountable.
At the other end of the spectrum, one transforms into an unrecognizable individual who feels he or she must change everything that the group has created so far and do things his or her way.
After all, the leader is ultimately responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behavior often leads to disagreements between leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Virtual team members often function as the point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet at different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real ‘invisible team’ (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique element of a virtual team.
The “invisible team” is the management team to which each member reports. It establishes standards for each of them.

Why would an organization want to impose the time-consuming process of creating an organizational learning structure ? One of the objectives related to the implementation of organizational learning concepts is innovation.
When all available resources are used effectively in the functional services of an organization, creativity and ingenuity can fully express themselves.
Therefore, the process of an organization working together to overcome an obstacle can lead to a new innovative process to meet the client’s need.
Before an organization is innovative, its leadership must create an innovation culture, shared knowledge and its own learning culture.

Neuro-biological data provide concrete evidence for a theoretical approach to the study of cognition. They therefore reduce the scope of research and make it much more precise.
The correlation between brain pathology and behavior supports scientists in their research.
We know for a long time that different types of damage, lesions, tumours and brain injuries affect behavior and cause changes in certain mental functions.
The rise of new technologies allows us to see and study brain structures and processes that have never been seen before.
It gives us a lot of information and material to build simulation models that help us understand the processes in our minds.

Although artificial intelligence is often strongly associated with science fiction, it represents a very important part of computer science that studies the behaviour, learning and intelligent adaptation of a machine.
Artificial intelligence research aims to automate tasks requiring intelligent approaches.
Among the examples are control, planning and programming, the ability to answer client diagnoses and questions, as well as recognition of writing, voice and face.
These practices have led to distinct disciplines, focused on providing solutions to everyday life problems.
The AI system is now often used in the fields of economics, medicine, engineering, and the military, as it has been used in several home computer and video game software.
Excursions are an integral part of any school class. Often, a teacher would like to take his or her students to places where a bus journey is not possible.

The solution is provided by technology in the form of virtual educational outings. Students can look at old objects in a museum, visit an aquarium, or admire a beautiful artwork while sitting with their class.
Practically participating in an excursion is also a great way to think about a trip and share your experiences with future generations.

For example, students at Bennet College in North Carolina design each year a website dedicated to their visit to the state capital. Each year, the website is updated, but the old versions are kept online to serve as an album.

Blogs can also help students improve their writing skills. Even though students often try the blogging experience with poor grammar and spelling, the fact of having a public audience usually improves the situation.
As students are often the most critical audience, the author of the blog begins to strive to improve his or her writing to avoid criticism.
In addition, blogging "obliges students to better understand the world around them". The need to attract the public's interest encourages students to be intelligent and interesting (Toto, 2004).
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

"When used properly, blogs can allow students to strengthen their analytical and critical thinking abilities: by actively reacting to online content, they can confront their opinions with those of others and expose their own points of view on specific topics" (Oravec, 2002).
Ottawa is the charming bilingual capital of Canada and has a large number of art galleries and museums that highlight the past and present of Canada.
You will find more to the south the Niagara Falls and to the north, the Muskoka region and its environs, which have a natural beauty that is unspoiled.
All of these measures, and many more, make Ontario what foreigners consider to be the quintessence of Canada.
Large areas further north are fairly sparsely populated and some are almost uninhabited in the wild.
For a comparison that surprises more than one: There are more African-Americans living in the United States than Canadian citizens.
The East African islands are in the Indian Ocean, off the east African coast.
Madagascar is by far the largest country, and even a continent on its own, in terms of fauna.
Most of the smaller islands are independent nations, or associated with France, and are known for luxury resorts.
The Arabs also brought Islam to the islands and this religion spread widely to Comoros and Mayotte.
European influence and colonialism began in the 15th century, at the time when Portuguese explorer Vasco de Gama discovered the Cape route that links Europe to India.
To the north, the region is bounded by the Sahel, and to the south and west by the Atlantic Ocean.

It is also advisable to wear a wedding ring (which should not seem too precious).

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 9th century BCE, and was used by Phoenicians, Romans, and the Almohads as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who after having destroyed it had rebuilt it and called it Casa Branca, abandoned it in 1755 after a earthquake.
The Sultan of Morocco rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina, it is easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tajines, pottery, leather goods, narguilés and all kinds of trinkets, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town in the eastern portion of the Democratic Republic of Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano which buried most of the streets of the city, in particular the downtown.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma should be researched to understand the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.
The town is also the starting point for the climb to the Nyiragongo Volcano as well as for the least expensive gorilla tracking treks in Africa.
You can use boda-boda (motorcycle taxi) to get around Goma. The normal (local) price is about 500 Congolese francs for a short ride.
Combined with its relative remoteness, "Tombouctou" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.
Today Tombouctou is a poor city, despite its reputation as a tourist attraction, and it has an airport.
In 1990, it was added to the endangered sites list due to the threat of sand dunes.
It was one of the main steps in Henry Louis Gates' PBS show "Wonders of the African World".
The city contrasts sharply with other cities in the country, as it has a style more Arabic than African.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa and runs along the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the Crocodile River border to the south.
The total area of the park is 19,500 km², which is divided into 14 ecozones, each of which is home to a specific fauna.
This is one of the most famous amusement parks in South Africa and considered the crown jewel of SANParks.
As with all South African national parks, there are daily entry and conservation fees for the park.
It can be advantageous to purchase a Wild Card which gives access to some of South Africa's parks as well as to all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and is the main attraction for many tourists.
The row of skyscrapers that forms the horizon of Hong Kong has been compared to a sparkling bar graph reflecting in the waters of Victoria Harbour.
To admire the most beautiful views of Hong Kong, leave the island and head to Kowloon Bay on the other side.
The majority of Hong Kong's urban development is concentrated on the northern landfill sites.
This is the place that the British colonists invested. So it seems like a good starting point, if you are looking for evidence of colonial history in this region.
The Sundarbans are the world's largest coastal mangrove belt stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coastline to the backwaters of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans were declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located in India is called the Sundarbans National Park.
However, forests are not composed only of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last vestiges of the majestic jungles that once covered the plains of the Ganges.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km², of which approximately one third is covered by water/marshy areas.
Sundarbans is a nature reserve since 1966, you can find about 400 Royal Bengal Tigers and 30,000 spotted deer.

Bus departs from the intercity bus station (on the other side of the river) throughout the day, but most, particularly those that serve east and Jakar/Bumthang, depart between 6:30 and 7:30 in the morning.
Inter-district buses are often full, so it is advisable to buy a ticket a few days in advance.
Most districts are served by small Japanese fishing boats, which are comfortable and robust.
Collective taxis are a quick and comfortable way to get to places nearby, such as Paro (150 Nu) and Punakha (200 Nu).
The Oiapoque Bridge is a suspension bridge. It overlooks the Oyapock River to connect the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers stand at a height of 83 metres; it is 378 metres long and has two lanes of 3.5 metres wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 metres. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it was opened to traffic in March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guarani were the most important indigenous group inhabiting what is now the east of Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes who inhabited the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived mainly through fishing, hunting, or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay, formerly known as the “Great Province of the Indies”, was born from the meeting between the Spanish conquerors and the indigenous populations.
Spain inaugurated the period of colonialism, which lasted for three centuries.
Since the founding of Asunción in 1537, Paraguay has been able to maintain a large part of its character and identity as an indigenous nation.
Argentina is known for having one of the best teams and among the best polo players in the world.
The biggest tournament of the year takes place in December on the polo fields of Las Cañitas.
In addition, smaller tournaments and matches are sometimes held here at other times of the year.
For information on polo tournaments and where to buy tickets for polo matches, consult the Argentine Polo Association.
The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands Pound (FKP), which is equivalent to a British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank in Stanley, on the other side of the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a widely accepted currency in the islands, while at Stanley, American dollars and credit cards are also often accepted.
On the neighbouring islands, credit cards will probably not be accepted, even if British and American currency may be accepted. Talk to the owners beforehand to agree on a method of payment.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falkland Islands outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.
Montevideo is located south of Ecuador, so winter in the northern hemisphere corresponds to summer there and vice versa.
Montevideo is located in the subtropical zone and summer temperatures exceeding 30 °C are common.
Winter can be deceivingly cold: temperatures rarely fall below zero, but wind and humidity combine to give the impression that it is colder than the thermometer says.
There is no such thing as a “rainy season” and a “dry season”: rainfall is fairly constant throughout the year.
Although many of the animals in the park are used to seeing humans, they are wild animals; please do not feed them or disturb them.
According to the park authorities, you need to keep at least 100 metres away from bears and wolves and 25 metres away from all other wild animals.
As docile as they may seem, bison, elk, moose, bear, and almost all large animals can attack.
Each year, dozens of visitors are injured because they didn't keep enough distance. These animals are large, wild and potentially dangerous, so give them space.
Also be aware that odors attract bears and other wild animals, so avoid carrying or cooking smelly foods and keep the camp clean.
Apia is the capital of Samoa. The city is located on the island of Upolu and has a population of about 40,000.
Apia was founded in the 1850s and is the official capital of Samoa since 1959.
The port was the site of a notorious naval impasse in 1889, when seven ships from Germany, the United States, and Britain refused to leave the port.
All the ships were sunk, with the exception of a British cruiser. Nearly 200 Americans and Germans lost their lives.
The supreme leader Tupua Tamasese Lealofi III was assassinated during a peaceful rally that was held in the city, during the struggle for independence organized by the Mau movement.
There are many beaches, as Auckland is on two harbours. The most popular ones are in three areas.
The North Shore beaches (in the North Harbour district) are located on the Pacific Ocean and stretch from Long Bay to Devonport.
Most beaches are sandy and allow safe swimming, and most are shaded by pohutukawa.
Tamaki Drive Beach is located on the Waitemata Harbour in Mission Bay and Saint Heliers in the heart of Auckland.
These beaches, sometimes very popular with families, have many shops along the shore. Swimming is safe there.
The main local beer is the “Number One”, a fairly ordinary beer, but tasty and refreshing. There is also another local beer, the “Manta”.
There are many French wines to taste, but New Zealand and Australian wines may travel better.
You can drink local tap water without danger, but you can easily find bottled water if you have concerns about it.

Many reef cruises are conducted throughout the year, and injuries due to one of these causes on the reef are rare.
Nevertheless, follow the advice of the authorities, obey all signs and pay close attention to safety warnings.

Sharks exist, but they rarely attack humans. Most of them are afraid of humans and would run away from them.
Saltwater crocodiles do not live actively in the ocean, their main habitat is in the estuaries of rivers north of Rockhampton.
Booking in advance gives the traveller the peace of mind that he will have somewhere to sleep once he arrives at his destination.
Travel agencies often have agreements with specific hotels, but you can also book through travel agencies of other types of accommodation, such as camping areas.
Travel agencies usually offer packages that include breakfast, airport transfers, or packages that combine flight and accommodation.
They may also hold your reservation for you if you need time to think about the offer or obtain other documents needed for your destination (for example, a visa).
Any changes or requests must be addressed to the travel agency first and not directly to the hotel.

Anyone who drives to high latitudes or crosses mountain passes should consider the possibility of snow, ice or cold temperatures.
On icy and snowy roads, the friction is low and you cannot drive as if you were on bare asphalt.
During blizzards, it can fall in very little time enough snow to block you.
Visibility can also be limited by snow or dust or condensation or ice on the windows of vehicles.
On the other hand, the presence of ice and snow is normal in many countries, and traffic is practically uninterrupted all year round.

In common parlance, the term "safari" refers to an excursion on the African continent, and in particular in the savanna, with the aim of witnessing the spectacular spectacle of wild animals in their natural environment.
Some animals, such as elephants and giraffes, tend to approach too closely to cars and standard equipment allows good observation.
Le lion, le guépard et le léopard are sometimes shy and you will see them better with binoculars.
A walking safari (also known as bush walking, walking safari, or footing) is about walking, either for a few hours or for several days.

Tokyo will be the only Asian city to have hosted two summer Olympic Games, after hosting the Games in 1964.

In some places, boiling water for one minute is enough; in others, it takes several minutes.
The effectiveness of filters varies, and if you have a problem, you should consider buying bottled water from a reputable company.
Travelers may encounter animals they do not know in their home region.
Parasites can contaminate food, cause irritations, or, in the most serious cases, cause allergic reactions, spread venom or transmit infections.
Infectious diseases themselves, or dangerous animals that can injure or kill people by force, are generally not considered parasites.
In some localities, duty-free shops present an opportunity to buy goods exempted from taxes and excise duties.
Travelers to countries where taxes are high may sometimes save considerable amounts, especially on products like alcohol and tobacco.
The section between Point Marion and Fairmont presents the most difficult driving conditions on the Buffalo-Pittsburgh highway, passing frequently through isolated backcountry areas.
If you are not used to driving on rural roads, keep your mind open: steep slopes, narrow lanes and tight curves are common.
The posted speed limits are substantially lower than in the previous and following sections – usually 35 to 40 mph (56 to 64 km/h) – and strict enforcement is still more important than before.
However, mobile service is surprisingly strong here compared to many other parts of the road, for example the Pennsylvania Wilds.
German pastries are rather good, and in Bavaria they are very rich and varied, similar to those of their southern neighbor, Austria.
Fruit pastries are common: apples are cooked and baked into pastries all year round, while cherries and plums appear in summer.
Many German bakery products contain almonds, hazelnuts and other nuts. Popular baked goods often pair particularly well with a strong cup of coffee.
If you want small but copious pastries, try Berliner Balls, also known as Berliner, Pfannkuchen or Krapfen according to regions.
A curry is a dish made of herbs and spices, accompanied by meat or vegetables.
A curry dish can be solid or liquid, depending on the amount of sauce it contains.
In northern India and Pakistan, yogurt is commonly used in curries; in southern India and some other coastal regions of the subcontinent, coconut milk is commonly used.
Indonesia is home to 17,000 islands, and the Indonesian cuisine is a generic term that covers a wide variety of regional cuisines found throughout the country.
However, when this term is used without any other qualification, it tends to refer to foods from the central and eastern parts of the main island of Java.

Now widely available throughout the archipelago, Javanese cuisine offers a range of simply seasoned dishes, the predominant flavours that the Javanese favour being peanuts, peppers, coconut sugar (especially Javanese coconut sugar) and various aromatic spices.
The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang from each side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the saddle, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth and narrow sole.
Then, some saddles, notably the English ones, have safety bars that allow a bridle to fall off the saddle if it is pulled backwards by a rider who falls.

Skiing and snowboarding are popular winter sports which consist of sliding down a snowy slope with skis or a snowboard attached to the feet.
Skiing is a major travel activity that has many fans, sometimes called "ski bums", who organise their entire holiday around skiing in specific places.
The idea of skiing is very old: cave paintings showing skiers date back to 5,000 BCE!
Skiing as a sport dates back at least to the 17th century, with the first leisure ski club founded in 1861 in Australia by Norwegians.
Nordic walking: this activity is also called Nordic skiing, cross-country skiing or cross-country skiing.
It looks like alpine skiing, as well as mountaineering, without incorporating in general these activities, which are practiced on rough terrain and require the use of much stiffer skis and boots.
Think of the ski route as a similar hiking route.
In good conditions, you can cover a little more distance on foot – but you won't reach the speeds of cross-country skiing without a heavy backpack on a dammed trail.

Europe is a relatively small continent, but containing many independent countries. Travelling across several countries therefore involves having to apply for multiple visas and undergo multiple passport checks.
However, the Schengen area works somewhat like a single country in this regard.
As long as you are in this zone, you can usually cross borders without having to go through passport control points.
As long as you have a Schengen visa, you do not need to separately apply for a visa for each of the Schengen countries, which saves time, money and administrative formalities.
There is no universally accepted definition of antiquity. Some tax authorities define items over 100 years old as antiques.
The criteria vary by location; in some parts of the world, such as North America, the age limit may be lower than in Europe.
Artisanal products can be considered antiques even if they are less ancient than similar industrial products.
Ranching reindeer is an important means of subsistence for the Sami and the culture surrounding this trade is important to many other professions.

Nowadays, many Sámi people practice modern jobs. Tourism is an important source of income in Lapland, the Sámi region.

Violent weather is the generic term for any weather phenomenon that is dangerous enough to cause damage, major social disruption or human life loss.
Very adverse weather conditions can occur anywhere in the world, and they can be of many kinds, depending on the geographic, topographic and atmospheric characteristics.
Violent winds, hail, excessive rainfall and fires are forms and effects of violent weather, just as thunderstorms, tornadoes, tidal waves and cyclones.
Extreme weather phenomena, regional and seasonal, include cold storms, snow storms with strong winds, and sandstorms or dust storms.
It is strongly advised that travellers check the weather conditions in their destination area, knowing that this can have an impact on the itineraries they plan.

The undertow is the current that comes back from waves breaking on the beach, often on a reef or equivalent.
Because of the underwater topography, the return flow is concentrated on a few deeper sections, and a fast current toward the deep waters can form.
In most cases, deaths are due to exhaustion that results from trying to swim against the current, which can be impossible.
As soon as you leave the current, the return to swimming is no more difficult than usual.
Try to aim for an area where you won't be taken again. It is also possible that, depending on your skills and whether you have been spotted or not, you may want to wait for the rescue.

The official languages of Barcelona are Catalan and Spanish. About half of the inhabitants prefer to speak Catalan, a large majority can understand it, and practically everyone is able to speak Spanish.

Japanese work culture is more hierarchical and formal than that which Westerners may be used to.
Costumes are traditional workwear, and employees are called by their family name or job title.
Workplace harmony is crucial because it emphasises collective effort rather than individual achievement.
Workers must often obtain approval from their supervisors for any decisions they make and are expected to follow instructions from their supervisors without question.
